data.text:
Tom Steitz

Thomas Steitz, born August 23, 1940, is a Sterling Professor of Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry, Howard Hughes Medical Institute, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut, USA. Steitz received his bachelorâ€™s of arts degree from Lawrence College in 1962 and adoctoral degree in molecular biology and biochemistry in 1966 from Harvard University. He was a postdoctoral fellow at Harvard in1966-67 and at the MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology, Cambridge, England from 1967-70. He joined Yale as a faculty member in 1970.

Steitz was awarded the 2009 Nobel Prize in Chemistry along with Venkatraman Ramakrishnan and Ada Yonath "for studies of the structure and function of the ribosome".Steitz also won the Gairdner International Award in 2007 "for his studies on the structure and function of the ribosome which showed that the peptidyl transferase was an RNA catalyzed reaction, and for revealing the mechanism of inhibition of this function by antibiotics". In 2007, Steitz was one of four recipients of the Gairdner International Awards, joining his wife, Joan Steitz, Sterling Professor of Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry as a recipient of the prestigious award.
